position.marginalia_text: Jus à iubendo; grammatica, et logica notatio: Jus à; ethica, et ciuilis allusio.

marginalia.translation: Law from what is ordered: grammatical and logical notation. Law from justice: ethical and civil allusion.

position.marginalia_text: Jurisprudentia Romana, vel Juris Romani Ars: nouissimè edita, ab Hermanno Vulteio, et Joanne Althusio: vtriusq[ue] duobus libris, quasi ad Leges methodi Ramea[e] conformata. Vulteij liber 1. de Jure Absoluto; in personis, et Rebus: illo in Potestate, et Obligatione: hoc, in possessione, et dominio. L[iber] 2 de Jure Relato; in praxi superioris Juris, i[n] Judicio. Althusij l[iber] 1. de Jure primo; quod in Acquirendo, et Amittendo consistit. L[iber] 2. de Jure Orto à primo, i[n] Judicio; in quo Actiones, earumq[ue] processus.

marginalia.translation: 'Iurisprudentia Romana, vel Iuris Romani Ars', recently published by Hermann Vulteius and Johannes Althusius, in two books conforming to Ramus's laws of method. Book 1 by Vulteius, on absolute law, is divided into that of persons and that of things, the former into power and obligation, the latter into possession and ownership. Book 2, on relative law, superior in practice, when it comes to an actual court case. Book 1 by Althusius, on first law, which consists of gains and losses. Book 2, on law arising from first law in an actual court case, in which there are suits and their process.

position.marginalia_text: Necessaria[e] Bartholi Distinctiones, ad Digestorum Methodum composita[e]: et his Paratitlis vtilissimè connectenda[e], suo qua[e]q[ue] loco. Vndè in pla[e]risiq[ue] ciuilibus negotijs, pra[e]gnantissima Disputandi, et Decidendi Vis. Cum Hopperi libris 4. ad Pandectas, vel de iure ciuili priuato. In quibus ciuilis ratio cuiusq[ue] materia[e], expeditiss[im]è est exposita. Vt antè breuissimè, in quarto Elementorum.

book.title: Paratitla seu synopsis pandectarum iuris ciuilis
Ad Pandectas, sive de iure civili privato

marginalia.translation: Bartolus's 'Distinctiones', arranged according to the method of the 'Digest', is essential, as is the 'Paratitla', usefully attached in its proper place. Here is the most pregnant source of powerful debate and decision-making, in almost all civil affairs. With Hoppers's 'Ad Pandectas, sive de iure civili privato', in four books, in which he expeditiously sets out civil reasoning and its material, just as he had done briefly before, in the fourth book of the 'Elementorum'.
